title: How to Cancel Auto Shutdown in Windows 10

steps.title: Press Win+R (to open Run) or open Command Prompt or PowerShell.
steps.content: Press Win+R (to open Run) or open Command Prompt or PowerShell. Pressing the Win + R key combination will open the Run window. You'll find Command Prompt or PowerShell in your Start menu . Since PowerShell is replacing Command Prompt for many modern Windows 10 computers, you can also select PowerShell in the menu that pops up when you press Win + X . [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Enter the following command:
steps.content: Enter the following command: shutdown -a . This command will cancel the scheduled shutdown for one time. You'll have to repeat this process if you want to cancel other scheduled shutdowns.

steps.title: Click OK (in the Run window) or ↵ Enter (in Command Prompt or PowerShell).
steps.content: Click OK (in the Run window) or ↵ Enter (in Command Prompt or PowerShell). It's below the place where you entered the code in the Run window and will prompt it to close. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Open Settings.
steps.content: Open Settings. You can press Win + I to open Settings, or you can find it in your Start menu next to a gear icon.

steps.title: Click System.
steps.content: Click System . It should be the first icon in the menu. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Power and sleep.
steps.content: Click Power and sleep . You should see this in the menu on the left side of the window. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Additional power settings.
steps.content: Click Additional power settings . This is towards the right side of the window. [5] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Change plan settings.
steps.content: Click Change plan settings . You'll see this to the right of your current plan.

steps.title: Click Change advanced power settings.
steps.content: Click Change advanced power settings . It's under the general settings.

steps.title: Double-click Sleep and Sleep After.
steps.content: Double-click Sleep and Sleep After . Double-clicking these will expand their menus.

steps.title: Click On Battery or Plugged in, select the arrow and choose "Never" (laptop only).
steps.content: Click On Battery or Plugged in , select the arrow and choose "Never" (laptop only). If you want to change the setting for both of these options, repeat the process for the one you didn't already change. [6] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Setting, select the arrow and choose "Never" (desktop only).
steps.content: Click Setting , select the arrow and choose "Never" (desktop only). You will not see this if you're on a laptop. Changing the "Sleep" settings to "Never" will ensure that your computer never goes to sleep .

steps.title: Double-click Hibernate after.
steps.content: Double-click Hibernate after . A menu will expand below the header.

steps.title: Click On Battery or Plugged in, click the arrow and choose "Never" (laptop only).
steps.content: Click On Battery or Plugged in , click the arrow and choose "Never" (laptop only). If you want to change the setting for both of these options, repeat the process for the one you didn't already change.

steps.title: Click Setting, click the arrow and choose "Never" (desktop only).
steps.content: Click Setting , click the arrow and choose "Never" (desktop only). You will not see this if you're on a laptop. [7] X Research source These settings will ensure your computer never hibernates, which might drain your battery if your laptop is not plugged into a power source. [8] X Research source
